section.title: Shells
section.p: We can compute volumes of solids of revolution using cylindrical shells. These shells are formed by following a thin rectangular region as it rotates about an axis.

If the axis of rotation is perpendicular to the x-axis, then the volume is determined by V = \int_{\textrm{start}}^{\textrm{finish}} 2\pi (\textrm{radius from axis to rectangle})(\textrm{height of rectangle}) \; dx

If the axis of rotation is perpendicular to the y-axis, then the volume is determined by V = \int_{\textrm{start}}^{\textrm{finish}} 2\pi (\textrm{radius from axis to rectangle})(\textrm{height of rectangle}) \; dy

introduction.p: Consider the region in the first quadrant bounded by y=x^2, y=0, and x=2. Use cylindrical shells to determine the volume of the object obtained by rotating that region about the following axes:

Use cylindrical shells to show the volume of a cone with height h and radius r is \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h. Rotate a triangular region about an axis to obtain a cone with vertex at the origin in the xy-plane.
Use cylindrical shells to show the volume of a sphere with radius r is \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3. Rotate a semi-circular region centered at the origin to obtain the sphere.
